newsitem.title: USA: No painless way to fund the Big Dig-taxpayer group.
newsitem.headline: No painless way to fund the Big Dig-taxpayer group.

text.p: A taxpayers group has found that the now $10.4 billion Third Harbor/Central Artery project, known as the Big Dig, will put Massachusetts into heavy bondage.
Massachusetts Taxpayers Foundation analyzed the funding plan for what is the most expensive highway construction project in the country.

It found that despite the proposed issuance of at $1.1 billion of revenue bonds from the state's Turnpike Authority, $900 million of government anticipation notes, $200 million of Port Authority revenue bonds and $50 million from Massahusetts Bay Transportation Authority in capital funds, there still will not be enough money to finance the project.

State transportation officials say the good government group failed to take into consideration that the cost of the project is actually lower than planners originally estimated due to a lower rate of inflation.

But the Taxpayer's Foundation warns that for the state to be able to afford its share of the project, "immediate increases in tolls on Boston Harbor tunnels, the Boston Turnpike extention and the Tobin Bridge" are required and "in all likelihood ever higher toll increases will be necessary."

The group said, "In the absence of adequate toll revenue, the Commonwealth faces two undesireable alternatives -- sacrficing much of the state highway program and other important non-highway capital needs, or increasing a broad based tax such as the gas tax."
Republican Gov. William Weld is unlikely to agree to an increase in any tax and just last year during the election season eliminated the part of the state's tax on gasoline.

Also, Beacon Hill legislators, who acknowledge the state's courts are in desperate need of repairs, are still struggling with the passage of a $685 million general obligation issue to fund new court houses. They too are hesistant to increase taxes.

The taxpayer's group, noting the uncertainty of continued federal financing for the project, suggested that for the "Legislature the challenge is striking the proper balance between granting the administration the flexibility it will need to respond rapidly to changing fiscal events and preserving a prudent level of fiscal control."
